bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Micajah and Richard Perry, July 22, 1720

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchants, Micajah and Richard Perry, July 22, 1720, concerning bills of exchange and tobacco shipped on board the Carter, including 9 hogsheads belonging to Daniel McCarty. He notes that he has received a report of sales they had sent with Capt. Friend, and that he is pleased with the price fetched. He turns to his son John's pleas of repentance about his spending and attention to his studies and states that he will not remonstrate further if John keeps to his promises. His debt from Edward Hastewell still disturbs him, and he hopes the Perrys will assist John Bashford. He concludes with a remark about the South Sea stock, Parliament's "Falling into a Design that Threatens ruin to the nation, " and that all things political are presently calm in the colony.

div1.head:
Letter from Robert Carter to Messrs. [Micajah
and Richard] Perry, July 22, 1720

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
July 22d. 1720
Messrs. Perry

div1.p:
Herein comes some first bills of Excha. amounting
as per List to 198 pound wch. I desire Yor. managemt. of. Likewise here
wth. I send You a bill of Lading for 42 hogsheads of Tobo. on board the Carter
30 of them Stemd, also You have herein a bill of Lading
for 9 hogsheads of Tobo. belonging to Captn. McCarty wch. You are
to Accot. to him for,

I'm now to acquaint You wth.in this few days
I have received Yors. by Captn. Friend, I note Yor. sale of some more
of my Tobo. at 11d & 11 1/2 It will please me very well If You
hold out to the End at those prices,

My Son I find is upon the Stool of repentance
It twill be well he will come to his Senses at last he makes
me large promises to retrench himself & that he will for the
future call upon You for no more by the Quarter Than £37"10/
& will make the best use of his time that he has to stay in Engla[nd]
by a close application to his Study. These are agreeable
promises If he keeps to them, he hath sent me an accot.
of How the Taylors for £50 odd pound wch It seems I must
pay he Expects It will cost him some money to be calld to
barr wch. I must not Grudge at he beggs of me to forget his past
Extravagancys and desires I may not Insist upon a particular
Accot. from him, & that he will give me no more oaccasion of
future Complaints upon these termes I am willing to Shutt
up wth. him Thus You see I am no stranger to the Storey In
The Gospel—

I suppose before now You have closd the matter
wth. The whitehaven Gent., My Debt from Hastewell will
never go out of my mind, but that seems to be more pro=
=perly the care of another Person, Bashfords business hath
bin knotty & troublesome & but a trifle in the bottom. If
You can be the Instrument to help him to his right at
last, You will Do a very Charitable Act & he will be
bound to pray for You,

You say a great deal about the South
Sea Stock It is all mysterious to me Its a great wonder
The Lords and commons Should agree in Falling into a
Design that Threatens ruin to the nation I must leave
It to Wiser heads Than mine, as for my annuity I have
already said Enough about It—

Politicks Jarrs here I hope will be laid aside
for some time at least all things at present carry the
face of Peace a most Comprehensive word of all
Sublunary blessings—

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1720 July-1721 July, BR 227, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, San Marino, California. Printed: Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . pp. 34-35.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and state have been added for clarity.
[1] Edward Hastewell, a London merchant, had been one of the owners of the Carter.

[2] John Bashford (d. 1735) may have had problems, but in 1726, he was to present affidavits in Northumberland County court to prove his parentage and marriage because he had fallen heir to an estate in England. ("The Heaths of Northumberland County, Virginia," William and Mary Quarterly, 1st. ser., 24[1915]: 109-115.)

[3] RC refers to the South Sea Company whose stock in June 1720 was worth £1060 for each £100 share; the crash of the "Bubble" was underway even as he wrote. (Goldwin Smith, A History of England, p. 424.)
